  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "Contents:\n```Hey everyone, it's your bro. Hope you're doing well, and in this video I'm going to explain the binary search algorithm in computer science. So sit back, relax, and enjoy the show. Alright, binary search. It's a search algorithm that finds the position of a target value within a sorted array or other collection. In order for a binary search to work, whatever we're searching through, it needs to be sorted. And basically what we do is we take half of the array and eliminate it during each step, and we will whittle down our collection until there is only one element remaining. In this example, I have an array of 11 elements. Each element contains a letter, and they're all sorted alphabetically. Let's say we are looking for the letter h, and I need the index. What we would do with a binary search is that we always begin in the middle. We first check to see if our target value is equal to this middle value. If these are equal, then we can return this index, but odds are they're probably not going to be equal on the very first turn, the very first step. So these are not equal. Then we will check to see if our target value is greater than or less than this middle value. Since h is greater than f, we can disregard this entire first half of our array, because since this is sorted, our target value could not possibly be within this first portion. And then we begin step two, or phase two. It's the same process as before. So again, we begin in the middle, check to see if our target value is equal to the middle value. If they're not, check to see if our target value is greater than or less than the middle value. This time h is less than i. We would delete the second half of this portion. We're not actually deleting these values, we're disregarding them. And then we can move on to step three. We're repeating the same process as before, and this time these elements divide evenly. So we would just round down and begin and say that this is the middle. So h is greater than g. We would disregard this element, and we only have h remaining. So we would return this index, because these values are equal. And that's a binary search. Now a binary search isn't too efficient when working with small data sets. However, if you're working with a large data set, like one million elements, well then a binary search is actually fantastic, because we're eliminating half of the elements we are searching through during each phase or turn. So if we had a million elements after the first phase, we can already disregard like half a million elements, and then we just repeat the process until there's only one left. So if this was an iterative approach, we would need to search through these linearly, beginning with index zero and going all the way to a million. So a binary search is fantastic with large data sets. The runtime complexity of a binary search is O of log n. The larger the data set, a binary search becomes more and more efficient compared to other search algorithms. All right, let's perform a binary search in real life now. We'll use the builtin binary search method of arrays to begin with, and then later on we'll build our own binary search function. So we'll need an array to work with. Let's say we have an array of integers named array. Int array, and the size of this array will be 100. We'll increase the size later for demonstration purposes, and we'll need a target value that we're searching for. I'll just name this target. Int target equals, what about 42? We'll search for the number 42, and we'll need to populate our array. So we can do so using a for loop. Int i equals zero. We will continue this for loop as long as i is less than array dot length, and increment i by one during each iteration. Then we will fill array at index i with whatever i is, our index. Okay, so the cheap way of using a binary search is to use the builtin binary search method of arrays. Let's say int index equals arrays dot binary search. And taking a look at this binary search method, there's two arguments that we have to pass in. An array, and whatever we're searching for. So we will pass in our array and our target, then return the index. And let's display that. So let's check to see if our index is equal to negative one. If our target is not found, then that means negative one will be returned from our binary search method. So let's print something. System dot out dot print line. What about element not found? Actually better yet, target not found. Let me change that. Target plus not found. Okay, then else. Else we will display system dot out dot print line. Element found at colon space plus index. All right, let's try it. Okay, element found at 42. Cool. Now let's create our own binary search function for practice. I'll turn this line into a comment, copy it, paste it, and get rid of this erase portion. Okay, then I'm just going to use a shortcut to generate this function. Okay, so private static int binary search. There are two parameters, an array of integers named array and int target. So we'll return negative one. That acts as a sentinel value. Negative one means that the value was not found. Now what we'll need at this point is the beginning and ending index of our array. So let's say int low will be the beginning and int high is the end. Array dot length minus one. So we have a low index and high index and we'll create a while loop. While low is less than or equal to high, we'll continue this while loop and keep on searching through our array. So first we need the middle index. Int middle, and here's the formula for that, low plus high minus low divided by two. So we have our middle index. We will take int value equals our array at index of middle. So this will extract that value found within this element. Okay, so this portion is optional. If you have an if statement and you only have like one line of code, you don't really need the curly braces. I'm just doing this so it's easier to read. And by returning negative one, that means target not found. And that is our binary search function. Let's try it. Okay, element found at 42. And in that case, looping through an array would have a runtime complexity of O of N to find this number. It's going to take over 700,000 steps because we're iterating once for each element within this array compared to a binary search where it only took 20 steps. Consider what to return if the element is not found, such as a special value like -1 or an exception.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Rephrase Question\n\t- Definition: Rephrase the binary search problem to always have a unique answer by considering where to insert the element in a sorted array to maintain order. This approach ensures a consistent return value even if the element is not present.\n\t- Dependencies: Define Problem\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Set Bounds\n\t- Definition: Initialize the lower and upper bounds (low and high) for the search range. These bounds will be used to narrow down the search space iteratively.\n\t- Dependencies: Rephrase Question\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Compute the midpoint of the current search range using the formula mid = low + (high - low) // 2 to avoid overflow issues. This midpoint will be used to compare against the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Set Bounds\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Compare and Adjust\n\t- Definition: Compare the element at the midpoint with the target value. Adjust the lower or upper bound based on whether the midpoint element is less than or greater than the target. This step narrows the search range.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Check Convergence\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the lower and upper bounds converge by checking that the difference between them decreases in each iteration. This guarantees that the loop will eventually terminate.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare and Adjust\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Return Result\n\t- Definition: Return the index where the target value should be inserted to maintain order, which is the converged value of the lower and upper bounds. This index represents the first occurrence of the target if it exists.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Convergence\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Handle Variants\n\t- Definition: Consider variations of the binary search, such as finding the last occurrence of a target value. Adjust the comparison logic to handle these variants, like using less than or equal to for bisect right.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n```"

    "content": "Video 2:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Concept\n\t- Definition: Understand the concept of binary search using a real-world analogy, such as searching for a student's paper in a sorted stack. The key idea is to repeatedly divide the search space in half until the target is found or determined to be absent.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Algorithm Analysis\n\t- Definition: Analyze the efficiency of binary search. Understand that binary search operates in O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each comparison.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Recursive Implementation\n\t- Definition: Implement binary search using a recursive approach. Start with initial parameters for the left and right bounds of the search space. Handle base cases and recursive cases to search the left or right half based on comparisons.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Iterative Implementation\n\t- Definition: Convert the recursive binary search implementation into an iterative one. Use a loop to manage the search space boundaries and update them based on comparisons, avoiding recursion.\n\t- Dependencies: Recursive Implementation\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Handle Edge Cases\n\t- Definition: Consider potential pitfalls such as integer overflow when calculating midpoints. Implement solutions to handle these edge cases, such as using alternative midpoint calculations.\n\t- Dependencies: Recursive Implementation, Iterative Implementation\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Apply to Data Types\n\t- Definition: Apply the binary search algorithm to different data types, ensuring the data is sorted. Explore how binary search can be used beyond integers, such as with strings.\n\t- Dependencies: Recursive Implementation, Iterative Implementation\n```"

    "role": "user",
    "content": "Video 3:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Prerequisites\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the array or collection to be searched is sorted, as binary search requires a sorted dataset to function correctly.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Initialize Variables\n\t- Definition: Set up the initial variables needed for binary search, including the low and high indices that represent the current search range within the array.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Prerequisites\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Middle\n\t- Definition: Compute the middle index of the current search range using the formula: middle = low + (high - low) / 2. This helps in avoiding overflow issues.\n\t- Dependencies: Initialize Variables\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Compare Middle Value\n\t- Definition: Compare the value at the middle index with the target value. Determine if the target is equal to, less than, or greater than the middle value.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Middle\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Adjust Search Range\n\t- Definition: Based on the comparison, adjust the search range by updating the low or high index. If the target is greater than the middle value, set low to middle + 1. If less, set high to middle - 1.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare Middle Value\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Repeat or Conclude\n\t- Definition: Repeat the process of calculating the middle and adjusting the search range until the target is found or the search range is exhausted (low > high). Return the index if found, or -1 if not found.\n\t- Dependencies: Adjust Search Range\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Implement Iteratively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using an iterative approach, typically with a while loop that continues until the search range is exhausted.\n\t- Dependencies: Repeat or Conclude\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Implement Recursively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using a recursive approach, where the function calls itself with a reduced search range until the base case is met.\n\t- Dependencies: Repeat or Conclude\n```"

    "content": "Video 4:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Binary Search\n\t- Definition: Explain the concept of binary search, including how it efficiently finds an element in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. Discuss the advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Define Function Signature\n\t- Definition: Define the function signature for the binary search implementation, specifying the parameters such as the array, the target element, and the left and right indices that define the current search bounds.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Binary Search\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Implement the calculation of the midpoint index of the current search interval using the formula `mid = left + (right - left) / 2` to avoid overflow issues.\n\t- Dependencies: Define Function Signature\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Check Midpoint Element\n\t- Definition: Check if the element at the midpoint is equal to the target element. If it is, return the midpoint index as the result.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Adjust Search Bounds\n\t- Definition: Adjust the search bounds based on the comparison of the midpoint element with the target. If the midpoint element is greater, search the left half; if less, search the right half.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Midpoint Element\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Handle Element Not Found\n\t- Definition: Implement the base case for when the element is not found, which occurs when the left index exceeds the right index. Return a special value (e.g., -1) to indicate the element is not present.\n\t- Dependencies: Adjust Search Bounds\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Test Implementation\n\t- Definition: Test the binary search implementation with various cases, including finding an element, not finding an element, and edge cases like searching for the first or last element.\n\t- Dependencies: Handle Element Not Found\n```"

If the number of elements is odd, choose the middle element. If even, choose the lower middle index.\n\t- Dependencies: Sort Array\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Compare Middle\n\t- Definition: Compare the middle element with the target value. Determine if the middle element is equal to, less than, or greater than the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Find Middle\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Adjust Search\n\t- Definition: Based on the comparison, adjust the search range. If the middle element is less than the target, search the right subarray. If greater, search the left subarray. Repeat the process with the new subarray.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare Middle\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Return Index\n\t- Definition: If the middle element is equal to the target value, return the index of the middle element as the result of the search.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare Middle\n```"

    "content": "Subgoals:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Concept\n\t- Definition: Understand the concept of binary search, including how it efficiently finds an element in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. Discuss the advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Ensure Sorted\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the array or list is sorted before performing a binary search. This is a prerequisite for the binary search algorithm to function correctly.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Define Problem\n\t- Definition: Decide whether the binary search should return the index of the found element or the element itself. Consider what to return if the element is not found, such as a special value like -1 or an exception.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Set Bounds\n\t- Definition: Initialize the lower and upper bounds (low and high) for the search range. These bounds will be used to narrow down the search space iteratively.\n\t- Dependencies: Ensure Sorted\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Compute the midpoint of the current search range using the formula mid = low + (high - low) // 2 to avoid overflow issues. This midpoint will be used to compare against the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Set Bounds\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Compare and Adjust\n\t- Definition: Compare the element at the midpoint with the target value. Adjust the lower or upper bound based on whether the midpoint element is less than or greater than the target. This step narrows the search range.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Check Convergence\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the lower and upper bounds converge by checking that the difference between them decreases in each iteration. This guarantees that the loop will eventually terminate.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare and Adjust\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Return Result\n\t- Definition: Return the index where the target value should be inserted to maintain order, which is the converged value of the lower and upper bounds. This index represents the first occurrence of the target if it exists, or a special value if not found.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Convergence\n- **Subgoal 9**:\n\t- Title: Handle Variants\n\t- Definition: Consider variations of the binary search, such as finding the last occurrence of a target value. Adjust the comparison logic to handle these variants, like using less than or equal to for bisect right.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 10**:\n\t- Title: Implement Iteratively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using an iterative approach, typically with a while loop that continues until the search range is exhausted.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 11**:\n\t- Title: Implement Recursively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using a recursive approach, where the function calls itself with a reduced search range until the base case is met.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 12**:\n\t- Title: Algorithm Analysis\n\t- Definition: Analyze the efficiency of binary search. Understand that binary search operates in O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each comparison.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 13**:\n\t- Title: Test Implementation\n\t- Definition: Test the binary search implementation with various cases, including finding an element, not finding an element, and edge cases like searching for the first or last element.\n\t- Dependencies: Implement Iteratively, Implement Recursively\n```"
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "Contents:\n```Hello and welcome. I'm James Murphy, and today we're talking about binary search. Binary search, also called bisection search, is an algorithm for finding an element quickly in a sorted array. Suppose we're trying to find 7 in this array. Is it in the left half or the right half? The right half. And then repeat. Finally, there's just one element left. That's our 7. Even though it's one of the first algorithms that one learns, it's also extremely important. Analyzing binary search is often the branching point for studying things like time complexities of algorithms and big O notation. Here you can see we started with 8 elements, and at each step we ruled out half of them. This idea of ruling out half of all the possibilities at each step is where binary search or bisection search gets its name. This is also where it gets its logarithmic time complexity from. So binary search is useful, fundamental, and simple. And yet, a huge percentage of programmers, even professional programmers, struggle to write binary search. How can the idea be so simple, but the implementation be so difficult? Well, it's not so difficult. You just have to think about it in the right way. The first thing we should decide on is, are we returning the object that we find, or the index that it was at? The index itself is a more useful piece of information. We can always just grab the object at that index later. But what do we do if the object we're looking for isn't there? Do we do something like return negative one, or maybe raise an exception? Or what if there are multiple valid indices to choose from? With every arbitrary choice that we make, we would have to remember the implementation details that go with that choice. A better way to do it is to rephrase the question so that there is always exactly one answer. So here's how I would rephrase the question. If I were going to add another seven into this sorted array, where should I put it so that it's the first seven? Notice that in this hypothetical, I'm always adding the seven into the array. That guarantees the array is nonempty and always contains at least one seven. But if it contains at least one seven, then there is always a unique first seven. The index of that first seven is the answer to my question. It doesn't matter whether or not the original array had a seven or multiple sevens in it. The location of the first seven in the new array is always uniquely determined. If there were no sevens, I would have to put it here to maintain the sorting property. And if there are already sevens, it would have to be the index of the first already existing one. Even if the array were empty, I still get a valid answer. In this case, I would have to insert the seven at index zero. Notice that zero is not a valid index into this array, but it still makes sense because the question that I asked was where should I insert it. And it certainly makes sense to insert it at index zero. The same applies for a nonempty array. Binary search might tell me that I have to put it at the end. As long as you keep in mind this interpretation of what binary search is supposed to return, it's much harder to get confused. I think that far too often binary search is taught solely as an algorithm that works on sorted arrays. But the array being sorted, I claim, is not actually the property that we're using here. Here, look, I changed some of the elements and this array is no longer in sorted order. But notice the steps are exactly the same. What we need is that everything less than seven is on the left and everything bigger than seven is on the right. In this array, the numbers have been replaced with the important information. Is this number less than seven? Notice how any trues are on the left and any falses are on the right. So now that we're looking at the relevant data, where do we insert seven so that it is the first seven? Notice that the answer that we're looking for is the index of the first false value, or the end of the array if there are no false values. This is the key insight that we need to keep in mind that makes the implementation extremely easy to remember. Squint your eyes and find the first false value. Okay, let's write the implementation. Low and high are lower and upper bounds on where this first false index is. Zero would mean the first value is false and length of the array would mean that all of the values are true, so we would need to put x at the end. The idea is that we are going to continually increase our lower bound and decrease our upper bound until they're equal. Low and high will meet at the unique index that we're looking for, so we could return either low or high. It makes no difference. We compute mid, which is the closest index to the middle between low and high. Python can represent arbitrarily large integers so we don't need to worry about overflow, but if you're doing this in another language besides Python you might have to worry about overflow. In that case you can represent the midpoint equivalently by writing it as low plus half the distance between low and high. If you write it this way it will never overflow. Next comes the part of the algorithm that is most often written incorrectly. We need to compare whatever's in the array at the midpoint with our given x and then update the lower or upper bound accordingly. Remember we're looking for the first false value where true or false is determined by asking the question, is this less than x? Well in this section the middle value is less than x. It is a true value. Since the value at mid is a true value the earliest a false value could occur is the next one, which is mid plus one. What about if we see a false value? In this case the first false value couldn't be any later than mid because there is a false value at mid, but it could be earlier. There might be other false values before the one that we've found. That means the best we can do is update our upper bound to be whatever mid is. And there you have it. This is a correct implementation. But how can we reason about it? How do we know that this actually gives the right answer? Well we know that low is always less than or equal to the correct answer is always less than or equal to high, and we do keep updating the lower and higher bounds, but how do we know that they actually meet so that the loop stops? It's enough to show that every iteration the difference between high and low always decreases by at least one. If we enter this clause the plus one ensures that low always increases by at least one. In this clause we're setting high to mid, so hopefully we're lowering high, but how do we know that mid was actually strictly less than high? Here we're actually using that integer division rounds down. Inside the while loop low is less than high, so low plus high is strictly less than high plus high. That means that when we divide by two and round down we'll get something strictly less than high. It's common to take low and high as optional parameters so that if you already have a lower or upper bound you can make use of that. And of course don't forget to check that the parameters are valid. And that's all there is to it. But wait, you ask, instead of returning the index to insert a 7 so that it would be the first 7, couldn't I also return the index so that it would be the last 7? Yeah, you could. You could follow essentially the same analysis and get a very similar algorithm. To find where it should go to be the first 7, the relevant piece of information is is it strictly less than 7. To find where it should go to be the last 7, you want to know is it less than or equal to 7. In either case the index that you're looking for is the first false value. You just need to decide on what you mean by true and false. The first one is called bisect left and the second bisect right. So this one that we already wrote is bisect left. Can you tell me what you need to change in order to make it bisect right? Here's an example of how you might use bisect left. For this function we want to find the index of the first x in the array or throw an error if there isn't one. Since we're looking for the first index we'll use bisect left. If there is already an x in the array, bisect left will return the index of the first one. So we would like to just check at that index and see if we see an x. If we don't get back a valid index or if we find that there is not an x at the location that bisect left told us to look at, then there's no x in the array so we raise an error. The last thing that I want to mention is that the bisect library in Python already has bisect left and bisect right implemented for you. So if you need to do a bisection, prefer using the builtin Python bisect library. You don't need to install anything in order to use it. That's all I have for today. I hope this helped you understand binary search a little bit better. If you like this video please consider subscribing. And as always don't forget to slap that like button an odd number of times.```"
  }
]

      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So now that we're looking at the relevant data, where do we insert seven so that it is the first seven?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Notice that the answer that we're looking for is the index of the first false value, or the end of the array if there are no false values."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "This is the key insight that we need to keep in mind that makes the implementation extremely easy to remember."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Squint your eyes and find the first false value."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Okay, let's write the implementation."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Low and high are lower and upper bounds on where this first false index is."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Zero would mean the first value is false and length of the array would mean that all of the values are true, so we would need to put x at the end."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "The idea is that we are going to continually increase our lower bound and decrease our upper bound until they're equal."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Low and high will meet at the unique index that we're looking for, so we could return either low or high."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It makes no difference."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We compute mid, which is the closest index to the middle between low and high."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Python can represent arbitrarily large integers so we don't need to worry about overflow, but if you're doing this in another language besides Python you might have to worry about overflow."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "In that case you can represent the midpoint equivalently by writing it as low plus half the distance between low and high."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "If you write it this way it will never overflow."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Next comes the part of the algorithm that is most often written incorrectly."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We need to compare whatever's in the array at the midpoint with our given x and then update the lower or upper bound accordingly."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Remember we're looking for the first false value where true or false is determined by asking the question, is this less than x?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Well in this section the middle value is less than x."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It is a true value."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Since the value at mid is a true value the earliest a false value could occur is the next one, which is mid plus one."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "What about if we see a false value?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "In this case the first false value couldn't be any later than mid because there is a false value at mid, but it could be earlier."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "There might be other false values before the one that we've found."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That means the best we can do is update our upper bound to be whatever mid is."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And there you have it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "This is a correct implementation."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "But how can we reason about it?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "How do we know that this actually gives the right answer?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Well we know that low is always less than or equal to the correct answer is always less than or equal to high, and we do keep updating the lower and higher bounds, but how do we know that they actually meet so that the loop stops?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It's enough to show that every iteration the difference between high and low always decreases by at least one."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "If we enter this clause the plus one ensures that low always increases by at least one."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "In this clause we're setting high to mid, so hopefully we're lowering high, but how do we know that mid was actually strictly less than high?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Here we're actually using that integer division rounds down."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Inside the while loop low is less than high, so low plus high is strictly less than high plus high."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That means that when we divide by two and round down we'll get something strictly less than high."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It's common to take low and high as optional parameters so that if you already have a lower or upper bound you can make use of that."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And of course don't forget to check that the parameters are valid."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And that's all there is to it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "But wait, you ask, instead of returning the index to insert a 7 so that it would be the first 7, couldn't I also return the index so that it would be the last 7?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Yeah, you could."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You could follow essentially the same analysis and get a very similar algorithm."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "To find where it should go to be the first 7, the relevant piece of information is is it strictly less than 7."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "To find where it should go to be the last 7, you want to know is it less than or equal to 7."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "In either case the index that you're looking for is the first false value."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You just need to decide on what you mean by true and false."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "The first one is called bisect left and the second bisect right."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So this one that we already wrote is bisect left."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Can you tell me what you need to change in order to make it bisect right?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Here's an example of how you might use bisect left."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "For this function we want to find the index of the first x in the array or throw an error if there isn't one."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Since we're looking for the first index we'll use bisect left."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "If there is already an x in the array, bisect left will return the index of the first one."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So we would like to just check at that index and see if we see an x."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "If we don't get back a valid index or if we find that there is not an x at the location that bisect left told us to look at, then there's no x in the array so we raise an error."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "The last thing that I want to mention is that the bisect library in Python already has bisect left and bisect right implemented for you."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So if you need to do a bisection, prefer using the builtin Python bisect library."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You don't need to install anything in order to use it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That's all I have for today."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I hope this helped you understand binary search a little bit better."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "If you like this video please consider subscribing."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And as always don't forget to slap that like button an odd number of times."
      }

    "role": "user",
    "content": "Subgoals:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Concept\n\t- Definition: Understand the concept of binary search, including how it efficiently finds an element in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. Discuss the advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Ensure Sorted\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the array or list is sorted before performing a binary search. This is a prerequisite for the binary search algorithm to function correctly.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Define Problem\n\t- Definition: Decide whether the binary search should return the index of the found element or the element itself. Consider what to return if the element is not found, such as a special value like -1 or an exception.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Set Bounds\n\t- Definition: Initialize the lower and upper bounds (low and high) for the search range. These bounds will be used to narrow down the search space iteratively.\n\t- Dependencies: Ensure Sorted\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Compute the midpoint of the current search range using the formula mid = low + (high - low) // 2 to avoid overflow issues. This midpoint will be used to compare against the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Set Bounds\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Compare and Adjust\n\t- Definition: Compare the element at the midpoint with the target value. Adjust the lower or upper bound based on whether the midpoint element is less than or greater than the target. This step narrows the search range.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Check Convergence\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the lower and upper bounds converge by checking that the difference between them decreases in each iteration. This guarantees that the loop will eventually terminate.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare and Adjust\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Return Result\n\t- Definition: Return the index where the target value should be inserted to maintain order, which is the converged value of the lower and upper bounds. This index represents the first occurrence of the target if it exists, or a special value if not found.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Convergence\n- **Subgoal 9**:\n\t- Title: Handle Variants\n\t- Definition: Consider variations of the binary search, such as finding the last occurrence of a target value. Adjust the comparison logic to handle these variants, like using less than or equal to for bisect right.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 10**:\n\t- Title: Implement Iteratively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using an iterative approach, typically with a while loop that continues until the search range is exhausted.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 11**:\n\t- Title: Implement Recursively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using a recursive approach, where the function calls itself with a reduced search range until the base case is met.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 12**:\n\t- Title: Algorithm Analysis\n\t- Definition: Analyze the efficiency of binary search. Understand that binary search operates in O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each comparison.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 13**:\n\t- Title: Test Implementation\n\t- Definition: Test the binary search implementation with various cases, including finding an element, not finding an element, and edge cases like searching for the first or last element.\n\t- Dependencies: Implement Iteratively, Implement Recursively\n```"
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "Contents:\n```Hi, I'm Gail LockeMcDowell, author of Cracking Coding Interview. Today I'm going to cover binary search. So binary search is a very intuitive algorithm, and I'm going to show how intuitive it is by giving an example. You're a teacher and you're teaching a group of students, a very large class of 300 students, and you have their papers alphabetized out in front of you when a student, Zach Peters, comes up to get his paper back. So you probably wouldn't go through the papers, starting with Alex to Andy to Andrew, and then to Bob and Brenda and Brandy, and then to Chris and Christine, and you probably wouldn't do it that way. What you'd probably do is open the paper, open the stack of papers to roughly halfway through the papers and compare it. Zach Peters, well, then you open up halfway through and you see Michael Matters there, and you'd say, okay, Zach Peters is after that name. And then you take the second stack of papers and you'd treat it as its own little stack, and you'd again say, okay, let me open up to its midpoint. Maybe we see Sarah. Well, is Sarah before or after Zach Peters? And then you just go and repeat this process over and over and over again until you find Zach's paper, or until you find out Zach can't be in here. And this is the basics of binary search. So in an integer array it looks like this. You take some element that you're looking for, like 13, and you compare it to the midpoint. And it has to be a sorted array for this to work, it's very important. And you compare it to the midpoint. 13 is less than this midpoint, and so 13, if it's in the array at all, it has to be on the left side. And then you'd repeat this process on the left side and say, let me look at the midpoint of the left side. Is 13 before and after that? Before or after that? And you just repeat that process until you either find 13 or you know that 13 can't be in it. So how fast is this algorithm? Well, let's imagine we start off with n elements. So we have a search space of n elements. In a single comparison, just one, we've cut our search space down to n over 2. Then with one more comparison we cut it down to n over 4, and then and half again and half and half and half and half again. So how many total operations, in the very worst case, will we have to run until we figure out if it contains an element or not? Well, the total number of operations we'll have to do is determined by how many times can we divide n by 2 until we get down to just 1. So this is what log of n expresses, or log base 2 of n expresses. So if you pause the video, you can study that math for a second and see the relationship between those two things. But this means that binary search is a log n problem. Let's look now at the implementation of binary search. To implement binary search, we can either implement it recursively or iteratively. We'll do a recursive implementation first. So I'm going to just copy and paste here some just straightforward code for the binary search call. So this is an initial method that calls off to this binary search recursive method with the right parameters. So we're going to start off initially with left being 0 and right being the very right point. So these are inclusive endpoints. So first of all, if things get kind of too big, if left winds up bigger than right, then we know we have an error, we can't find it, and we want to return true. Otherwise, we want to pick the midpoint. So left dot right divided by 2, that's going to be the midpoint. And if we found the element, if array of mid is actually this element we're looking for, then we should return true. Otherwise, if x is on the left side of mid, then go search the left side. So pass an array, x, and left will stay as is and the right point will move to one next to the mid. Otherwise, go search the right side. So we want to call a very similar method, but now the left point moves up to mid plus 1 and right stays as is. Ok, so that's how the binary search recursive implementation looks. So one little minor pitfall is that, and some people like to be careful of it, is that left plus right can actually overflow with java integers. So if you'd like to avoid the integer overflow issue, you can actually just do this instead and this will prevent the overflow. It's kind of up to you, but this is one way of doing it. Ok, so now that we've done the recursive implementation, let's turn to the iterative implementation. So what I'm going to do is I'm going to actually tweak this recursive implementation. I'm going to copy paste it into a new function and I'm going to tweak it to make it iterative. So I'm going to call this iterative and I no longer need parameters in here, but what I'm going to do is I'm going to set, so I'm going to show you how you can tweak it. So I'm going to set left to be that right is going to start off at the rightmost position in the array. So now I want to iterate as long, I want to loop through this as long as left and right are such in the correct positions. So change this to a while loop. Alright, and then if I exit here then I haven't found it. Ok, so this looks correct and then here I don't want to actually recurse anymore. What I want to do is essentially take these values here. So left is going to stay as is and right is going to move to mid minus 1. I'm going to comment that out and I'll delete it shortly. And then here, rather than, so left is going to stay, or left is going to become mid plus 1 and right is going to stay as is. So that's how easy it is to tweak it from recursive to iterative. So that's how we implement binary search. Now remember that it can be implemented recursively or iteratively and it can also be applied to other data like strings or something else, but it must always operate on something that's sorted. So now that you've seen the implementation of binary search, why don't you try to do binary search on a new data type like a string. Good luck!```"
  }

      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And you compare it to the midpoint."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "13 is less than this midpoint, and so 13, if it's in the array at all, it has to be on the left side."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And then you'd repeat this process on the left side and say, let me look at the midpoint of the left side."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Is 13 before and after that?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Before or after that?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And you just repeat that process until you either find 13 or you know that 13 can't be in it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So how fast is this algorithm?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Well, let's imagine we start off with n elements."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So we have a search space of n elements."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "In a single comparison, just one, we've cut our search space down to n over 2."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Then with one more comparison we cut it down to n over 4, and then and half again and half and half and half and half again."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So how many total operations, in the very worst case, will we have to run until we figure out if it contains an element or not?"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Well, the total number of operations we'll have to do is determined by how many times can we divide n by 2 until we get down to just 1."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So this is what log of n expresses, or log base 2 of n expresses."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So if you pause the video, you can study that math for a second and see the relationship between those two things."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "But this means that binary search is a log n problem."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Let's look now at the implementation of binary search."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "To implement binary search, we can either implement it recursively or iteratively."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We'll do a recursive implementation first."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'm going to just copy and paste here some just straightforward code for the binary search call."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So this is an initial method that calls off to this binary search recursive method with the right parameters."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So we're going to start off initially with left being 0 and right being the very right point."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So these are inclusive endpoints."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So first of all, if things get kind of too big, if left winds up bigger than right, then we know we have an error, we can't find it, and we want to return true."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Otherwise, we want to pick the midpoint."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So left dot right divided by 2, that's going to be the midpoint."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And if we found the element, if array of mid is actually this element we're looking for, then we should return true."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Otherwise, if x is on the left side of mid, then go search the left side."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So pass an array, x, and left will stay as is and the right point will move to one next to the mid."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Otherwise, go search the right side."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So we want to call a very similar method, but now the left point moves up to mid plus 1 and right stays as is."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Ok, so that's how the binary search recursive implementation looks."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So one little minor pitfall is that, and some people like to be careful of it, is that left plus right can actually overflow with java integers."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So if you'd like to avoid the integer overflow issue, you can actually just do this instead and this will prevent the overflow."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It's kind of up to you, but this is one way of doing it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Ok, so now that we've done the recursive implementation, let's turn to the iterative implementation."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So what I'm going to do is I'm going to actually tweak this recursive implementation."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I'm going to copy paste it into a new function and I'm going to tweak it to make it iterative."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'm going to call this iterative and I no longer need parameters in here, but what I'm going to do is I'm going to set, so I'm going to show you how you can tweak it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So I'm going to set left to be that right is going to start off at the rightmost position in the array."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So now I want to iterate as long, I want to loop through this as long as left and right are such in the correct positions."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So change this to a while loop."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Alright, and then if I exit here then I haven't found it."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Ok, so this looks correct and then here I don't want to actually recurse anymore."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "What I want to do is essentially take these values here."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So left is going to stay as is and right is going to move to mid minus 1."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I'm going to comment that out and I'll delete it shortly."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And then here, rather than, so left is going to stay, or left is going to become mid plus 1 and right is going to stay as is."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So that's how easy it is to tweak it from recursive to iterative."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So that's how we implement binary search."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Now remember that it can be implemented recursively or iteratively and it can also be applied to other data like strings or something else, but it must always operate on something that's sorted."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So now that you've seen the implementation of binary search, why don't you try to do binary search on a new data type like a string."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Good luck!"
      }
    ]

    "role": "user",
    "content": "Subgoals:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Concept\n\t- Definition: Understand the concept of binary search, including how it efficiently finds an element in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. Discuss the advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Ensure Sorted\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the array or list is sorted before performing a binary search. This is a prerequisite for the binary search algorithm to function correctly.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Define Problem\n\t- Definition: Decide whether the binary search should return the index of the found element or the element itself. Consider what to return if the element is not found, such as a special value like -1 or an exception.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Set Bounds\n\t- Definition: Initialize the lower and upper bounds (low and high) for the search range. These bounds will be used to narrow down the search space iteratively.\n\t- Dependencies: Ensure Sorted\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Compute the midpoint of the current search range using the formula mid = low + (high - low) // 2 to avoid overflow issues. This midpoint will be used to compare against the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Set Bounds\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Compare and Adjust\n\t- Definition: Compare the element at the midpoint with the target value. Adjust the lower or upper bound based on whether the midpoint element is less than or greater than the target. This step narrows the search range.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Check Convergence\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the lower and upper bounds converge by checking that the difference between them decreases in each iteration. This guarantees that the loop will eventually terminate.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare and Adjust\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Return Result\n\t- Definition: Return the index where the target value should be inserted to maintain order, which is the converged value of the lower and upper bounds. This index represents the first occurrence of the target if it exists, or a special value if not found.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Convergence\n- **Subgoal 9**:\n\t- Title: Handle Variants\n\t- Definition: Consider variations of the binary search, such as finding the last occurrence of a target value. Adjust the comparison logic to handle these variants, like using less than or equal to for bisect right.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 10**:\n\t- Title: Implement Iteratively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using an iterative approach, typically with a while loop that continues until the search range is exhausted.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 11**:\n\t- Title: Implement Recursively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using a recursive approach, where the function calls itself with a reduced search range until the base case is met.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 12**:\n\t- Title: Algorithm Analysis\n\t- Definition: Analyze the efficiency of binary search. Understand that binary search operates in O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each comparison.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 13**:\n\t- Title: Test Implementation\n\t- Definition: Test the binary search implementation with various cases, including finding an element, not finding an element, and edge cases like searching for the first or last element.\n\t- Dependencies: Implement Iteratively, Implement Recursively\n```"

So sit back, relax, and enjoy the show. Alright, binary search. It's a search algorithm that finds the position of a target value within a sorted array or other collection. In order for a binary search to work, whatever we're searching through, it needs to be sorted. And basically what we do is we take half of the array and eliminate it during each step, and we will whittle down our collection until there is only one element remaining. In this example, I have an array of 11 elements. Each element contains a letter, and they're all sorted alphabetically. Let's say we are looking for the letter h, and I need the index. What we would do with a binary search is that we always begin in the middle. We first check to see if our target value is equal to this middle value. If these are equal, then we can return this index, but odds are they're probably not going to be equal on the very first turn, the very first step. So these are not equal. Then we will check to see if our target value is greater than or less than this middle value. Since h is greater than f, we can disregard this entire first half of our array, because since this is sorted, our target value could not possibly be within this first portion. And then we begin step two, or phase two. It's the same process as before. So again, we begin in the middle, check to see if our target value is equal to the middle value. If they're not, check to see if our target value is greater than or less than the middle value. This time h is less than i. We would delete the second half of this portion. We're not actually deleting these values, we're disregarding them. And then we can move on to step three. We're repeating the same process as before, and this time these elements divide evenly. So we would just round down and begin and say that this is the middle. So h is greater than g. We would disregard this element, and we only have h remaining. So we would return this index, because these values are equal. And that's a binary search. Now a binary search isn't too efficient when working with small data sets. However, if you're working with a large data set, like one million elements, well then a binary search is actually fantastic, because we're eliminating half of the elements we are searching through during each phase or turn. So if we had a million elements after the first phase, we can already disregard like half a million elements, and then we just repeat the process until there's only one left. So if this was an iterative approach, we would need to search through these linearly, beginning with index zero and going all the way to a million. So a binary search is fantastic with large data sets. The runtime complexity of a binary search is O of log n.         "type": "text",
        "text": "However, if you're working with a large data set, like one million elements, well then a binary search is actually fantastic, because we're eliminating half of the elements we are searching through during each phase or turn."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So if we had a million elements after the first phase, we can already disregard like half a million elements, and then we just repeat the process until there's only one left."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So if this was an iterative approach, we would need to search through these linearly, beginning with index zero and going all the way to a million."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {

  "goal": "The main purpose of the video is to explain and demonstrate the binary search algorithm, which is used to find the position of a target value within a sorted array.",
  "procedure": "The video begins by explaining the concept of binary search, which involves repeatedly dividing a sorted array in half to locate a target value. It then demonstrates using a built-in binary search method and proceeds to implement a custom binary search function. The process involves setting initial low and high indices, calculating the middle index, and adjusting the search range based on comparisons with the target value.",
  "outcome": "The outcome is a clear understanding of how binary search works, both using built-in methods and through custom implementation. The video demonstrates the efficiency of binary search, especially with large datasets, by showing how it significantly reduces the number of steps needed to find a target compared to linear search."

Given the contents of the how-to video and subgoals, segment the video according to subgoals. If some subtitles do not belong to any subgoal, define custom subgoals."

    "role": "user",
    "content": "Subgoals:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Concept\n\t- Definition: Understand the concept of binary search, including how it efficiently finds an element in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. Discuss the advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Ensure Sorted\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the array or list is sorted before performing a binary search. This is a prerequisite for the binary search algorithm to function correctly.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Define Problem\n\t- Definition: Decide whether the binary search should return the index of the found element or the element itself. Consider what to return if the element is not found, such as a special value like -1 or an exception.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Set Bounds\n\t- Definition: Initialize the lower and upper bounds (low and high) for the search range. These bounds will be used to narrow down the search space iteratively.\n\t- Dependencies: Ensure Sorted\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Compute the midpoint of the current search range using the formula mid = low + (high - low) // 2 to avoid overflow issues. This midpoint will be used to compare against the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Set Bounds\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Compare and Adjust\n\t- Definition: Compare the element at the midpoint with the target value. Adjust the lower or upper bound based on whether the midpoint element is less than or greater than the target. This step narrows the search range.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Check Convergence\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the lower and upper bounds converge by checking that the difference between them decreases in each iteration. This guarantees that the loop will eventually terminate.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare and Adjust\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Return Result\n\t- Definition: Return the index where the target value should be inserted to maintain order, which is the converged value of the lower and upper bounds. This index represents the first occurrence of the target if it exists, or a special value if not found.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Convergence\n- **Subgoal 9**:\n\t- Title: Handle Variants\n\t- Definition: Consider variations of the binary search, such as finding the last occurrence of a target value. Adjust the comparison logic to handle these variants, like using less than or equal to for bisect right.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 10**:\n\t- Title: Implement Iteratively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using an iterative approach, typically with a while loop that continues until the search range is exhausted.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 11**:\n\t- Title: Implement Recursively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using a recursive approach, where the function calls itself with a reduced search range until the base case is met.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 12**:\n\t- Title: Algorithm Analysis\n\t- Definition: Analyze the efficiency of binary search. Understand that binary search operates in O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each comparison.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 13**:\n\t- Title: Test Implementation\n\t- Definition: Test the binary search implementation with various cases, including finding an element, not finding an element, and edge cases like searching for the first or last element.\n\t- Dependencies: Implement Iteratively, Implement Recursively\n```"

    "content": "Contents:\n```In this video, I'm going to go over the binary search algorithm in C. So the binary search algorithm allows us to find an element in a sorted array with a much quicker process than we could find an element in an unsorted array. So with an unsorted array, if we wanted to find the index of element 12, where is it in the array, basically? We'd probably have to search from the lefthand side to the righthand side one element at a time, because really we have nothing to go on as to where 12 could be in this array. So we're kind of stuck searching one element at a time from the lefthand side to the righthand side until we find 12. In the case of a sorted array, though, we could find the element with a much smarter process. So in the case of a sorted array, if we want to find the element 12, it probably wouldn't make sense to start at the leftmost element and go to the right, because what we'd probably want to check first is the middle element. If we check that middle element and 12 is greater than that middle element, we know that 12 is not going to be on this lefthand portion of the array. We know it must be in this right portion of the array, because the array is sorted. And if 12 is greater than 7, then we're going to have that it must be on this side of the array here. And we could continually apply this process. So we know that the element 12 must be on this side of the array now. We might as well just apply that process again and check the middle element. Here there's an even number of elements. There's six. So we'd probably have to pick between 10 or 11. It actually wouldn't really matter which one we choose, but we'd pick between 10 or 11 here. So now we know that we don't have to consider this portion of the array. We can only look at this portion of the array. And what's happening here is that each time we sort of examine a middle element in some portion of the array where we want to find the element we're looking for, we're basically having each time the amount of remaining elements we need to look at. Because the first time we checked 7 here, we were able to eliminate half the elements in the array and say, we don't have to consider these. It can't be in there. And then we look at the remaining portion of the array here. We again have the elements that we need to look at. Because we looked at 10. We said, well, 12 must be in the righthand portion, because 12 is greater than 10. So we don't have to look at 8, 9, and 10. So again, we've wiped out half the elements. We don't have to look at these. And that's great. The less times we have to consider an element to see if that element is equal to 12, the faster it's going to be in terms of the algorithm and how long it takes to run. So now we'd only be looking at these three elements. And we'd say, let's look at the middle element here. And in this case, the middle element is going to be 12 itself. And we'd say, we're done. So a very, very fast algorithm, a very fast way of solving the problem, compared to this process here, where we had to check a bunch of elements here before we eventually found 12. And that's because a sorted array, it gives us some information to go on, to guide us, to find the element. So let's actually implement that process, which is called binary search. So we'll make a function here, int binarySearch. And the function is going to accept an array as an argument, the element we're looking for. And it's going to have a left index and a right index. So we're going to use the left and right index to constrain the portion of the array that we're looking at when we call this function. And we're going to actually solve this problem recursively by having the binary search function call itself with increasingly constrained portions of the array, where we're going to be looking for that element. So the first time we call the function, it's actually going to look like this. We'll say binarySearch, and we'll say try to find in the sorted array, we'll say the element 12. And the left index is going to be 0, and the right index is going to be 12. So the left and right index, they're going to be the leftmost index that we want to find 12 in potentially, and the rightmost index, where we want to find 12 in potentially. Because initially we want to try to find 12 in the entire array. And the leftmost index would be index 0, the rightmost index would be index 12, the last index in the array. Remember that arrays in C are zero index, so this 13th element here would actually be index 12. So that's what's going to happen the first time we call binarySearch, is we're going to call it basically trying to find this element in the entire array. But what we're going to do is we're going to continually examine the middle element in the array, and we're going to manipulate the left and right arguments to constrain the portion of the array in which we're trying to find the element. So let's actually first find the midpoint in the array. We'll say here int mid is equal to L plus R minus L divided by 2. So this is going to give us the midpoint in the portion of the array that we're considering. So when we try to find the midpoint initially, it's going to be the actual middle of the array itself. But eventually the midpoint is going to be something that's potentially the midpoint of a portion of the array. Because like let's say we're trying to find 12, right? Well then we're not we're not going to find it at 7. We're going to find that we have to look at this portion of the array. When we look at this portion of the array and we go to calculate the midpoint, we're going to want to look at the midpoint from the left index to the right index. So in this case the midpoint is not the midpoint of the entire array. The midpoint is going to be the midpoint of where the left index is and the right index. And that midpoint is not just like the midpoint of the array itself. It's the midpoint of this portion of the array. So if this math here looks a little bit more complicated, that's what's going on. We're saying basically find the midpoint from that left index to the right index. So then the first thing we're going to do is see if we found the element at the midpoint. So we'll say here if the array at the midpoint is equal to the element we're trying to find, we found it. And we could say return the midpoint because we found the element at the midpoint. Otherwise we're going to have to do the trickier step where we actually constrain the portion of the array that we're going to continue to look at. So we're going to say here else if the array at the midpoint is greater than the element that we're trying to look for. So if the array at the midpoint is greater than the element we're trying to look for, then we know the element we're trying to look for must be in the left portion of the array. Because if we're trying to look for let's say four, and at the midpoint here we've got seven, we know it must be in the lefthand portion of the array. So what we're going to do is we're going to return the result of calling binary search with that left portion of the array. So what this is going to do is it's going to basically keep the existing left index as the the new left index when we call binary search again, but the right index we're going to change now and we're going to change it to be mid minus one. Because if we just checked say element seven here and we just want to check to see you know where is four in this array here. Which makes sense because if we just look at seven we want to go up to here right one to the left of the current middle index. And then the final case here is we're going to say else if if it's this case we know that the element is actually greater than the middle index. So else if the element is greater than the middle index we're going to consider the right hand side of the array. So we'll say return binary search a e and we'll say here mid plus one r. So what we're doing this time is we're effectively altering the left index when we call binary search. And we're saying we want to now look at the the right hand portion of the array or the right hand portion of this section of the array that we're looking at.       "We might as well just apply that process again and check the middle element.",
      "Here there's an even number of elements.",
      "There's six.",
      "So we'd probably have to pick between 10 or 11.",
      "It actually wouldn't really matter which one we choose, but we'd pick between 10 or 11 here.",
      "We'd say this is the middle element.",
      "And we'd say, is 12 greater than this middle element? Or is it less than it? It's greater than that middle element.",
      "So now we know that we don't have to consider this portion of the array.",
      "We can only look at this portion of the array.",
      "And what's happening here is that each time we sort of examine a middle element in some portion of the array where we want to find the element we're looking for, we're basically having each time the amount of remaining elements we need to look at.",
      "Because the first time we checked 7 here, we were able to eliminate half the elements in the array and say, we don't have to consider these.",
      "It can't be in there.",
      "And then we look at the remaining portion of the array here.",
      "We again have the elements that we need to look at.",
      "Because we looked at 10.",
      "We said, well, 12 must be in the righthand portion, because 12 is greater than 10.",
      "So we don't have to look at 8, 9, and 10.",
      "So again, we've wiped out half the elements.",
      "We don't have to look at these.",
      "And that's great.",
      "The less times we have to consider an element to see if that element is equal to 12, the faster it's going to be in terms of the algorithm and how long it takes to run.",
      "So now we'd only be looking at these three elements.",
      "And we'd say, let's look at the middle element here.",
      "And in this case, the middle element is going to be 12 itself.",
      "And we'd say, we're done.",
      "We've found where 12 is in the array.",
      "And we only had to check three numbers.",
      "We only had to check 7, 10, and then we found 12.",
      "So a very, very fast algorithm, a very fast way of solving the problem, compared to this process here, where we had to check a bunch of elements here before we eventually found 12.",
      "And that's because a sorted array, it gives us some information to go on, to guide us, to find the element."

    "title": "Understand Concept",
    "explanation": "This segment explains the concept of binary search, how it works by dividing the search space, and its advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays."
  },
  {
    "quotes": [
      "So let's actually implement that process, which is called binary search.",
      "So we'll make a function here, int binarySearch.",
      "And the function is going to accept an array as an argument, the element we're looking for.",
      "And it's going to have a left index and a right index.",
      "So we're going to use the left and right index to constrain the portion of the array that we're looking at when we call this function.",
      "And we're going to actually solve this problem recursively by having the binary search function call itself with increasingly constrained portions of the array, where we're going to be looking for that element.",
      "So the first time we call the function, it's actually going to look like this.",
      "We'll say binarySearch, and we'll say try to find in the sorted array, we'll say the element 12.",
      "And the left index is going to be 0, and the right index is going to be 12.",
      "So the left and right index, they're going to be the leftmost index that we want to find 12 in potentially, and the rightmost index, where we want to find 12 in potentially.",
      "Because initially we want to try to find 12 in the entire array.",
      "And the leftmost index would be index 0, the rightmost index would be index 12, the last index in the array.",
      "Remember that arrays in C are zero index, so this 13th element here would actually be index 12.",
      "So that's what's going to happen the first time we call binarySearch, is we're going to call it basically trying to find this element in the entire array.",
      "But what we're going to do is we're going to continually examine the middle element in the array, and we're going to manipulate the left and right arguments to constrain the portion of the array in which we're trying to find the element."
    ],

    "explanation": "This segment introduces the implementation of binary search using a recursive approach, explaining how the function will call itself with constrained portions of the array."

    "quotes": [

  },
  {
    "quotes": [
      "So then the first thing we're going to do is see if we found the element at the midpoint.",
