      "And we could say return the midpoint because we found the element at the midpoint.",
      "Otherwise we're going to have to do the trickier step where we actually constrain the portion of the array that we're going to continue to look at.",
      "So we're going to say here else if the array at the midpoint is greater than the element that we're trying to look for.",
      "So if the array at the midpoint is greater than the element we're trying to look for, then we know the element we're trying to look for must be in the left portion of the array.",
      "Because if we're trying to look for let's say four, and at the midpoint here we've got seven, we know it must be in the lefthand portion of the array.",

      "So we'll say binary search return the result of calling binary search with the array, the element we want to find, and we're going to say here the left index and mid minus one.",
      "So what this is going to do is it's going to basically keep the existing left index as the the new left index when we call binary search again, but the right index we're going to change now and we're going to change it to be mid minus one.",

      "So that's going to then cut up the problem for us like that.",
      "Continue looking at the left portion of the portion of the array we're looking at and the right portion of the current portion of the array we're looking at."

  "procedure": "The video begins by explaining the concept of binary search, highlighting its efficiency over linear search in sorted arrays. It then proceeds to implement the binary search algorithm in C, using a recursive function that takes an array, the target element, and left and right indices as arguments. The function calculates the midpoint, checks if the target is at the midpoint, and recursively narrows the search to the left or right half of the array based on comparisons. It also handles the case where the element is not found by returning -1.",
  "outcome": "The final outcome is a working implementation of the binary search algorithm in C, which correctly finds the index of a target element in a sorted array or returns -1 if the element is not present."

    "role": "system",
    "content": "You are a helpful assistant specializing in analyzing and segmenting how-to videos according to task graph for How to implement binary search?.   {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "Subgoals:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Concept\n\t- Definition: Understand the concept of binary search, including how it efficiently finds an element in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. Discuss the advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Ensure Sorted\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the array or list is sorted before performing a binary search. This is a prerequisite for the binary search algorithm to function correctly.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Define Problem\n\t- Definition: Decide whether the binary search should return the index of the found element or the element itself. Consider what to return if the element is not found, such as a special value like -1 or an exception.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Set Bounds\n\t- Definition: Initialize the lower and upper bounds (low and high) for the search range. These bounds will be used to narrow down the search space iteratively.\n\t- Dependencies: Ensure Sorted\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Compute the midpoint of the current search range using the formula mid = low + (high - low) // 2 to avoid overflow issues. This midpoint will be used to compare against the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Set Bounds\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Compare and Adjust\n\t- Definition: Compare the element at the midpoint with the target value. Adjust the lower or upper bound based on whether the midpoint element is less than or greater than the target. This step narrows the search range.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Check Convergence\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the lower and upper bounds converge by checking that the difference between them decreases in each iteration. This guarantees that the loop will eventually terminate.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare and Adjust\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Return Result\n\t- Definition: Return the index where the target value should be inserted to maintain order, which is the converged value of the lower and upper bounds. This index represents the first occurrence of the target if it exists, or a special value if not found.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Convergence\n- **Subgoal 9**:\n\t- Title: Handle Variants\n\t- Definition: Consider variations of the binary search, such as finding the last occurrence of a target value. Adjust the comparison logic to handle these variants, like using less than or equal to for bisect right.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 10**:\n\t- Title: Implement Iteratively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using an iterative approach, typically with a while loop that continues until the search range is exhausted.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 11**:\n\t- Title: Implement Recursively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using a recursive approach, where the function calls itself with a reduced search range until the base case is met.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 12**:\n\t- Title: Algorithm Analysis\n\t- Definition: Analyze the efficiency of binary search. Understand that binary search operates in O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each comparison.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 13**:\n\t- Title: Test Implementation\n\t- Definition: Test the binary search implementation with various cases, including finding an element, not finding an element, and edge cases like searching for the first or last element.\n\t- Dependencies: Implement Iteratively, Implement Recursively\n```"

    "content": "Contents:\n```Welcome to TutorialsU, my name is Yannick and in this video we are going to talk about the binary search algorithm and we will take a look on how it is working in the background, so what exactly it is doing. So if you don't know the binary search algorithm yet, well, it's a very efficient way on how you can find an index of a specific value in an array or in a list, for example. So here we got an integer array and let's say we want to get the index of the value 6, so that would be 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, right, and the binary search method, as you can call on an array, for example, when you just put in the array and the value you are searching for will then return the index, so let's see if I hit start, that should be, like, 5, as I said, let's give it a moment, the number 6 is at index 5, just as I said. So let's start thinking about what is happening in the background and why this is a very efficient way on how you can find specific values. We also got the content of the video written as a blog article at our website, you can find the link for that in the description below. We also provide an example of a custom binary search using a Person class there, very exciting, so check it out. Now, understanding this algorithm is quite simple, so if we have an array, we just need to make sure that it is sorted, so this is, well, at very first one of the big downsides of this binary search, the array or the list or whatever collection you want to use, it has to be sorted, so for sure we can use link to sort that array and afterwards we can then use the binary search. Now, if we compare that to a linear search, the binary search is definitely way more efficient and this is because the binary search algorithm only has to iterate through the array logarithmically. Now, what exactly is he doing when we try to find the value 6? So, basically, what he's going to do is, we have in total, we have 7 elements here, right? 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, so we have an odd number of elements. He goes exactly into the middle of the array, so that would be 4. We got 1, 2, 3 on the left side, 5, 6, 7 on the right side. Now, if we have an even number of elements, so let's say, let me just add one here, we got 8 now, well, what is the middle, right? The middle is like 4.5, so the value between 4 and 5 is 4.5, great, or 4.5, just to make it easier for you to understand. So, in that way, he would go to 4.5. Now, if we have that odd number, as I said, he would simply go to 4. Now, he will see, okay, is this my value? We are searching for 6, right? Keep that in mind. So, he will see, okay, the value that I got in the middle is 4, but I'm searching for 6. So, no, this is not my value. We now have a left side from that 4 position where we are, now we have a right side. Now, I don't want to make it too complex in that code editor, this is why I now open up some smaller images, just to make a better visual representation of all of that. So, here we got our 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 array and keep in mind, we are searching for the value 6. As I said, he will now go into the middle of the array, which is 4, so we have a left side and a right side and he now checks, okay, is the middle value my desired value? No, but if it would be, the search would be completed, he would point to 6, he would say, all right, I immediately found the correct index. Now, 4 is smaller than 6, which basically means 6 is bigger, so he will go to the right side. If we would search for 2, he would go to the left side now. He would just perform that action again. So, let's say, okay, on the right side we got 5, 6, 7. Now, that chunk of the array will just, it will get repeated as it did before. Now, he will use that chunk of the array, 5, 6, 7, the right side from that middle outgoing and try to operate the same thing again. So, he will again take 5, 6, 7, go to the middle element and then we will have 5, 6, 7, as I said, and he will see, yes, that middle element this time is the correct one, right? So, he will say, yes, I found the correct element, I found the correct value and the index in that scenario is 5. So, this is basically what he's doing. He always goes to the next middle element. He takes the entire array, goes to the middle element, checks, is this the correct element? If yes, we're done. If not, is it bigger or smaller? If it's smaller, go to the left side. If it's bigger, go to the right side and this goes on and on and on and on until we found our element. So, right here, it's quite simple, right? Because we only have seven elements, but if we would have like a thousand, then this would be a lot of iterations. Great, and that's it already. So, this is how a binary search is working. Now, for all of you geeks out there, if you want to know it, the algorithm is super efficient because it has a time complexity of logarithmic, as I said it initially, in comparison to, let's say, a linear search, where we have O, N, where N is the size of the array. But in that case, we're going through the iterations or the iterations are passing through the array logarithmically and this is why it is more efficient. Now, if you want to gain more expert C Sharp knowledge, please check out our C Sharp Progress Academy, where you will learn full stack web development, including software design patterns in C Sharp and so much more. We offer a 14day moneyback guarantee, so you've got really nothing to lose. Check it out. The link is in the description below and I'm 100 sure that this is the fastest way on how you can progress as a C Sharp developer. So, thanks for watching. Make sure to subscribe to our channel. If you have any questions or any wishes for future videos, please write that down into the comment section below and I'm happy to see you back in the next video.```"

  "goal": "The main purpose of the video is to explain how the binary search algorithm works and demonstrate its efficiency in finding the index of a specific value in a sorted array.",
  "procedure": "The video begins by explaining the requirement for the array to be sorted. It then describes the binary search process: starting at the middle of the array, checking if the middle element is the target value, and deciding whether to search the left or right half of the array based on the comparison. This process is repeated until the target value is found.",
  "outcome": "The outcome is an understanding of how binary search efficiently finds the index of a target value in a sorted array, with a demonstration showing the index of the value 6 being found as 5."

    "role": "system",
    "content": "You are a helpful assistant specializing in analyzing and segmenting how-to videos according to task graph for How to implement binary search?. Given the contents of the how-to video and subgoals, segment the video according to subgoals. If some subtitles do not belong to any subgoal, define custom subgoals."

  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "Subgoals:\n```- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Understand Concept\n\t- Definition: Understand the concept of binary search, including how it efficiently finds an element in a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. Discuss the advantages over linear search in unsorted arrays.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Ensure Sorted\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the array or list is sorted before performing a binary search. This is a prerequisite for the binary search algorithm to function correctly.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Define Problem\n\t- Definition: Decide whether the binary search should return the index of the found element or the element itself. Consider what to return if the element is not found, such as a special value like -1 or an exception.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Set Bounds\n\t- Definition: Initialize the lower and upper bounds (low and high) for the search range. These bounds will be used to narrow down the search space iteratively.\n\t- Dependencies: Ensure Sorted\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Calculate Midpoint\n\t- Definition: Compute the midpoint of the current search range using the formula mid = low + (high - low) // 2 to avoid overflow issues. This midpoint will be used to compare against the target value.\n\t- Dependencies: Set Bounds\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Compare and Adjust\n\t- Definition: Compare the element at the midpoint with the target value. Adjust the lower or upper bound based on whether the midpoint element is less than or greater than the target. This step narrows the search range.\n\t- Dependencies: Calculate Midpoint\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Check Convergence\n\t- Definition: Ensure that the lower and upper bounds converge by checking that the difference between them decreases in each iteration. This guarantees that the loop will eventually terminate.\n\t- Dependencies: Compare and Adjust\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Return Result\n\t- Definition: Return the index where the target value should be inserted to maintain order, which is the converged value of the lower and upper bounds. This index represents the first occurrence of the target if it exists, or a special value if not found.\n\t- Dependencies: Check Convergence\n- **Subgoal 9**:\n\t- Title: Handle Variants\n\t- Definition: Consider variations of the binary search, such as finding the last occurrence of a target value. Adjust the comparison logic to handle these variants, like using less than or equal to for bisect right.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 10**:\n\t- Title: Implement Iteratively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using an iterative approach, typically with a while loop that continues until the search range is exhausted.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 11**:\n\t- Title: Implement Recursively\n\t- Definition: Implement the binary search algorithm using a recursive approach, where the function calls itself with a reduced search range until the base case is met.\n\t- Dependencies: Return Result\n- **Subgoal 12**:\n\t- Title: Algorithm Analysis\n\t- Definition: Analyze the efficiency of binary search. Understand that binary search operates in O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each comparison.\n\t- Dependencies: Understand Concept\n- **Subgoal 13**:\n\t- Title: Test Implementation\n\t- Definition: Test the binary search implementation with various cases, including finding an element, not finding an element, and edge cases like searching for the first or last element.\n\t- Dependencies: Implement Iteratively, Implement Recursively\n```"

      },

  "goal": "The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to implement binary search in Python, which is a more efficient search technique compared to linear search, especially for large sorted lists.",
  "procedure": "The video explains the binary search algorithm, starting with the requirement that the list must be sorted. It then describes setting initial lower and upper bounds, calculating the mid index, and comparing the mid value with the target. Depending on the comparison, the bounds are adjusted to narrow the search range. This process repeats until the target is found or the bounds overlap, indicating the target is not present. The video also includes a coding demonstration of this logic in Python.",
  "outcome": "By the end of the video, viewers should understand how to implement binary search in Python and see it successfully locate elements in a sorted list, or return 'not found' if the element is absent."
}
